(UK series 7)|I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here!]]'' *''[[Celebrity Big Brother (UK TV series)|Celebrity Big Brother]]'' * ''[[If Katie Hopkins Ruled the World]]''}} | spouse = {{plainlist| *{{marriage|Damian McKinney|2004|2005|end=divorced}} *{{marriage|Mark Cross|2010}}}} | children = 3 | website = {{url|hopkinsworld.com}} }}
'''Katie Olivia Hopkins''' (born 13 February 1975) is an English media personality, columnist, radio presenter and businesswoman. She was a contestant in the [[The Apprentice (UK series three)|third series of ''The Apprentice'']] in 2007 and following further appearances in the media she became a [[columnist]] for British national newspapers. She began writing for ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' in 2013<ref name="Guardian311013">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/oct/31/sun-katie-hopkins-daily-mail|title=Can the Sun's Katie Hopkins out-troll the Daily Mail?|work=The Guardian|date=31 October 2013|accessdate=24 September 2015}}</ref> and the ''[[Daily Mail]]''{{'}}s website ''[[MailOnline]]'' from 2015 to 2017.<ref name="Mayhew271117">{{cite news|last=Mayhew|first=Freddy|url=http://www.pressgazette.co.uk/katie-hopkins-leaves-mail-online-by-mutual-consent-as-column-is-axed-after-two-years/|title=Katie Hopkins leaves Mail Online by 'mutual consent' as column is axed after two years|work=Press Gazette|date=27 November 2017|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref> She has also been a presenter for the [[talk radio]] station [[LBC]].
Hopkins has been accused of [[racism]] by journalists, [[advocacy group]]s and politicians for her comments about [[Modern immigration to the United Kingdom|migrants]]. Her role at LBC was terminated in May 2017 following her comments on [[Twitter]] about the [[#Manchester Arena bombing|Manchester Arena bombing]].<ref name="The Independent">{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/kate-hopkins-lbc-radio-sacked-fired-manchester-attack-final-solution-daily-mail-muslims-racism-a7756776.html#gallery|title=Katie Hopkins to leave LBC 'immediately' in wake of Manchester attack 'final solution' comments|date=26 May 2017|work=The Independent|access-date=26 May 2017}}</ref><ref name="The Guardian">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/may/23/manchester-attack-police-investigate-katie-hopkins-final-solution-tweet|title=Katie Hopkins reported to police after 'final solution' Manchester attack tweet|date=23 May 2017|work=The Guardian}}</ref>
In 2016, ''Mail Online'' was forced to pay £150,000 to a Muslim family whom Hopkins had falsely accused of [[Islamic extremism|extremist]] links. In a 2017 [[Defamation#England and Wales|libel]] case, Hopkins was required to pay £24,000 in [[damages]] and £107,000 in [[Costs in English law|legal costs]] to the left-wing writer [[Jack Monroe]] after making defamatory remarks on Twitter. Later in 2017, ''Mail Online'' was forced to pay substantial damages and legal costs to a teacher about whom Hopkins had made false claims. A day before, in late November, it had become known Hopkins' contract with the media outlet had not been renewed.<ref name="Ruddick281117">{{cite news|last=Ruddick|first=Graham|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2017/nov/28/mail-online-damages-teacher-katie-hopkins-column|title=Mail Online to pay damages to teacher over Katie Hopkins column|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=28 November 2017|accessdate=28 November 2017}}</ref> Her final column was published on 5 October 2017.<ref name="Ruddick271117">{{cite news|last=Ruddick|first=Graham|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2017/nov/27/katie-hopkins-mail-online-column-contract-ends|title=Katie Hopkins' Mail Online contract ends 'by mutual consent'|work=The Guardian|date=27 November 2017|accessdate=27 December 2017}}</ref> She joined the Canadian [[far-right]] website [[The Rebel Media]] in January 2018.<ref name="Ruddick">{{cite news|last=Ruddick|first=Graham|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2018/jan/03/katie-hopkins-joins-far-right-canadian-website-rebel-media|title=Katie Hopkins joins far-right Canadian website Rebel Media|work=The Guardian|date=3 January 2018|accessdate=3 January 2018}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Katie Hopkins was born on 13 February 1975,<ref name="birth">''Index of Births, Marriages and Deaths in England and Wales, 1837–1983.''</ref> in [[Barnstaple]], Devon.<ref name=grigg/> Her father was an [[electrical engineer]] for the local Electricity Board and her mother was a bank teller. She has an older sister. She was raised in [[Bideford]],<ref name="Thring"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Bideford girl Katie Hopkins stars in Big Brother|url=http://www.northdevonjournal.co.uk/Bideford-girl-Katie-Hopkins-stars-Big-Brother/story-25853814-detail/story.html|accessdate=21 April 2015|work=North Devon Journal|date=14 January 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504125014/http://www.northdevonjournal.co.uk/Bideford-girl-Katie-Hopkins-stars-Big-Brother/story-25853814-detail/story.html|archivedate=4 May 2015}}</ref> attended a private [[convent school]] from age 3 to 16, played sports and learned to play the piano and violin. As a child she believed she was "going to be the colonel of the forces. I loved the military. I loved the discipline, the rigour, the big shouty men."<ref name="Aitkenhead">{{cite news|last=Aitkenhead|first=Decca|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2014/feb/14/katie-hopkins-interview|title=Katie Hopkins interview: 'Can you imagine the pent-up rage?'|work=The Guardian|date=14 February 2014|accessdate=19 December 2016}}</ref>
Hopkins told [[Sathnam Sanghera]] of ''[[The Times]]'' in June 2015 that she applied to study [[Philosophy, Politics and Economics]] (PPE) at [[Magdalen College, Oxford]]. She passed the [[University of Oxford|Oxford University]] entrance exam, but was rejected at the interview stage.<ref name="Sanghera"/> Disappointed, and putting the failure down to an absence of "a bit of coaching", she instead studied economics at the [[University of Exeter]]. She felt that her time at university was "redeemed" by her sponsorship from the [[British Army]]'s [[Intelligence Corps (United Kingdom)|Intelligence Corps]], and spent her weekends with the [[Officers' Training Corps]].<ref name="Sanghera"/> This she found "really fun, lying around in forests with guns having a brilliant time".<ref name="Aitkenhead"/>
She completed her military training at the [[Royal Military Academy Sandhurst]], but suffered an [[epilepsy|epileptic seizure]] during the final [[Passing out (military)|passing-out]] ceremony, and as a result was unable to take up her commission.<ref name="Sanghera"/> Hopkins said she kept her epilepsy secret whilst attending Sandhurst as this would have prevented her from being commissioned.<ref>{{cite news|title=Katie Hopkins talking about her epilepsy|url=https://www.epilepsy.org.uk/news/katie-hopkins-talking-about-her-epilepsy|accessdate=28 August 2017|work=Epilepsy Today|date=1 December 2010}}</ref> Instead, she joined a business consultancy and moved to [[Manhattan]], New York City, before returning to the UK in 2005.<ref name="Aitkenhead"/> She joined the [[Met Office]] as a global brand consultant in September 2006.<ref name=bbcmet/>
==Television and radio==
===''The Apprentice''=== {{main article|The Apprentice (UK TV series)|l1=The Apprentice}} Hopkins was allowed to take unpaid leave from her job from the Met Office as part of her probationary period of employment to take part in [[The Apprentice (UK series three)|series three]] of the reality TV show ''The Apprentice'' in 2006.<ref name=bbcmet>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/6743877.stm|title=Apprentice contender Katie fired|date=12 June 2007|accessdate=16 January 2015|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> In the format used at that time, contestants in ''The Apprentice'' competed for a £100,000-a-year job working for the businessman [[Alan Sugar]].<ref name=bbcmet/> Hopkins rejected Sugar's offer of a place in the final episode of the programme, citing problems regarding childcare provision for her daughters, and withdrew from the competition at the end of the penultimate task.<ref name=bbcmet/><ref name=cochrane>{{cite book|title=Women of the Revolution: Forty Years of Feminism|first=Kira|last=Cochrane|publisher=Guardian Books|year=2012|p=222|isbn=978-0-852-65262-6}}</ref> The episode gained 6.2 million viewers, while the following ''[[The Apprentice: You're Fired!|You're Fired]]!'' episode, in which Hopkins was interviewed, was watched by 3.1 million.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://media.guardian.co.uk/overnights/story/0,,2097470,00.html|title=The Apprentice beats Diana show|accessdate=15 June 2007|work=The Guardian | location=London | first=Leigh | last=Holmwood | date=7 June 2007}}</ref>
Throughout her tenure on ''The Apprentice'', Hopkins made several critical comments on camera. The comments were directed at her fellow contestants, viewers of television [[shopping channel]]s, [[maternity leave]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article1894251.ece|title=Last night's TV|accessdate=15 June 2007|work=The Times | location=London | first=Tim | last=Teeman | date=7 June 2007}}{{subscription required}}</ref> [[fake tan]]s, and overweight people.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/jul/05/katie-hopkins-apprentice-candidate-rent-a-gob|title=Katie Hopkins: from Apprentice candidate to rent-a-gob|accessdate=6 March 2015|work=The Guardian | date=5 July 2013}}</ref> ''[[Four Weddings and a Funeral]]'' and ''[[Notting Hill (film)|Notting Hill]]'' writer [[Richard Curtis]] expressed his distaste for Hopkins, jokingly vowing to kill her when he accepted his [[BAFTA Academy Fellowship Award|Fellowship award]] at the [[British Academy Television Awards 2007|2007 BAFTA awards]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/breaking/story.asp?j=253874945&p=z5387576x&n=253875831|title=Casualty stuns soap rivals to net first BAFTA|accessdate=15 June 2007|work=Irish Examiner}}</ref> When video clips of her comments about other candidates were shown on ''The Apprentice: You're Fired!'', following up on the main programme, Hopkins explained that they were "quite funny". [[Michelle Mone]], the founder of lingerie company [[Ultimo (lingerie)|Ultimo]] and a guest on the panel, verbally attacked Hopkins, calling her "exceptionally selfish", said she was not to be trusted, and accused her of giving "businesswomen a bad name".<ref>{{cite news|last=Symington-Mills|first=Louisa |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/womens-business/11303153/The-Apprentice-2014-Boardroom-bitches-Women-deserve-better.html|title=Boardroom bitches may be good for TV ratings. But businesswomen deserve better|work=The Daily Telegraph|location=London|date=19 December 2014|accessdate=16 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=John|last=Plunkett|title=The Apprentice – series three, episode 11|url=http://blogs.guardian.co.uk/organgrinder/2007/06/the_apprentice_series_three_ep_10.html|work=The Guardian |date=6 June 2007|accessdate=24 July 2007 | location=London|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070829052711/http://blogs.guardian.co.uk/organgrinder/2007/06/the_apprentice_series_three_ep_10.html#more|archivedate=29 August 2007}}</ref> Sugar was criticised over his questioning of Hopkins about her childcare arrangements.<ref name=cochrane/> He was accused of violating the 1975 [[Sex Discrimination Act 1975|Sex Discrimination Act]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article1901452.ece |title=Sugar faces sexism row as ex-Apprentice sells story |accessdate=15 June 2007 |work=The Times | location=London | date=8 June 2007 | first=Adam | last=Sherwin}}</ref> The incident received substantial media comment.<ref name=up>{{cite news|url=http://business.guardian.co.uk/comment/story/0,,2098403,00.html|title=All fired up|accessdate=15 June 2007 |work=The Guardian | location=London | date=8 June 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theherald.co.uk/features/features/display.var.1456687.0.0.php |title=Katie gone at last, but was the firing squad fair? |accessdate=15 June 2007 |work=The Herald |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070625120334/http://www.theherald.co.uk/features/features/display.var.1456687.0.0.php |archivedate=25 June 2007 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/film-tv/news/article2633484.ece |title=Sugar accused of sexism after apprentice quits |accessdate=15 June 2007 |work=The Belfast Telegraph |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20070711043827/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/film-tv/news/article2633484.ece |archivedate=11 July 2007 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/showbiz/sir-alan-accused-of-sexism-towards-apprentice-villain-katie-6588681.html|title=Sir Alan accused of sexism towards Apprentice villain Katie|work=<!-- Until 2009. -->Evening Standard|location=London|date=7 June 2007|accessdate=15 June 2007}}</ref> Sugar argued his case in an interview with [[GMTV]] host [[Fiona Phillips]], stating that he was aware of the rules.<ref name='GMTV'>{{cite episode|title=Sir Alan Sugar Interview|series=[[GMTV]]|station=[[ITV1]]|airdate=13 June 2007|season=14}}</ref>
====Aftermath==== In June 2007, Hopkins lost her job at the Met Office, which said that she did not meet the required standards to complete her probationary period, and confirmed that her performance on ''The Apprentice'' and confessions about her private life were a factor in her dismissal.<ref name="bbcmet" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rte.ie/arts/2007/0612/theapprentice.html |title=Katie Hopkins fired from real job |accessdate=15 June 2007 |publisher=Raidió Teilifís Éireann |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929155515/http://www.rte.ie/arts/2007/0612/theapprentice.html |archivedate=29 September 2007}}</ref> Hopkins later stated that the media were informed of her dismissal an hour after she was fired.<ref name='GMTV'/> After her appearance on ''The Apprentice'', Hopkins signed two deals to sell her story, one with the ''[[News of the World]]'' newspaper and the other with [[EMAP]], the company behind ''[[heat (magazine)|Heat]]'' and ''[[Grazia]]'' magazines.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk_news/story/0,,2097757,00.html|title=Apprentice star signs News of the World deal|accessdate=15 June 2007|work=The Guardian | location=London | first=Leigh | last=Holmwood | date=7 June 2007}}</ref>
Hopkins said in an interview with [[BBC Radio Kent]] that she had great respect for Sugar, and that she believed she would have won the programme had she been in the final episode. She also said that the media's attitudes towards her did not affect her but did affect her family.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/kent/realmedia/audio/kents_best/thursday.ram|title=Katie Hopkins BBC Radio Kent Interview |accessdate=15 June 2007|publisher=BBC Radio Kent}}</ref> She made a similar claim of hypothetical victory in an interview with Fiona Phillips on the morning of the final ''Apprentice'' episode, although Sugar had said that if she wanted to press on he would fire her, whoever she was competing with.<ref>{{cite episode|title=Katie Hopkins Interview|series=[[GMTV]]|station=[[ITV1]]|airdate=13 June 2007|season=14}}</ref> Hopkins told [[BBC Radio 1]] that she had not yet ruled out a media career<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediaselector/check/player/nol/newsid_6740000/newsid_6746800?redirect=6746827.stm&news=1&bbram=1&bbwm=1&nbram=1&nbwm=1&prefs=1 |title=Radio 1 Newsbeat – Katie Hopkins Interview |accessdate=15 June 2007 |publisher=BBC Radio 1}}</ref> but expressed interest in starting a business venture.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/berkshire/content/articles/2007/06/13/katie_hopkins_apprentice_feature.shtml |title=What Katie did next... |accessdate=14 June 2007|publisher=BBC Berkshire}}</ref>
===Broadcasting work=== After ''The Apprentice'', Hopkins appeared in an episode of ''[[8 Out of 10 Cats]]'', and was a guest star on ''[[Loose Women]]'' and ''[[The Friday Night Project]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://geo.channel4.com/entertainment/tv/microsites/F/fnp/episodes/s5_ep4.html|title=Show Four: Melanie C |accessdate=7 August 2007|publisher=Channel 4}}{{dead link|date=November 2014}}</ref> In 2007, she presented a ''Five Live Report'' on family life and working mothers for [[BBC Radio 5 Live]], and contributed an article on the same subject to [[BBC Online]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Katie |last=Hopkins |title=Gateway to the world feels just like a parish hall |url=http://www.thisisexeter.co.uk/displayNode.jsp?nodeId=136993&command=displayContent&sourceNode=244961&contentPK=17892541&folderPk=113914&pNodeId=244962 |publisher=Express and Echo |page=1 |date=21 July 2007 |accessdate=30 July 2007 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
In 2007, Hopkins joined the series ''[[I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here! (UK series 7)|I'm a Celebrity... Get Me Out of Here!]]''<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/money/2009/mar/21/the-apprentice-contestants|title=You're all fired|newspaper=The Guardian|first=Hazel|last=Davis|date=21 March 2009|accessdate=16 January 2015}}</ref> as a replacement for [[Malcolm McLaren]], who dropped out just before the show started.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/organgrinder/2007/nov/14/watchwiththeprospectofsee|title=Watch with ... the prospect of seeing the famous eat grim things|first=Anna|last=Pickard|newspaper=The Guardian|date=14 November 2007|accessdate=22 January 2016}}</ref> In January 2015, she took part in the [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]] reality series ''[[Celebrity Big Brother 15|Celebrity Big Brother]]'', finishing in second place.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/30780350|title=Celebrity Big Brother gets 233 complaints about Ken Morley|publisher=BBC News|date=12 January 2015|accessdate=16 January 2015}}</ref>
Hopkins has appeared twice on ''[[Question Time (TV series)|Question Time]]'' in the editions of 10 June 2010 and 27 January 2011. She also appeared on the Young Voters' version of ''Question Time'' on 20 October 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2010/10_october/20/voters.shtml |title=Press Office – Young Voters' Question Time panel announced |publisher=BBC |date=20 October 2010 |accessdate=30 October 2010}}</ref> She appeared on an episode of ''[[10 O'Clock Live]]'' on 24 April 2013 alongside [[Theo Paphitis]] and [[Owen Jones (writer)|Owen Jones]] to discuss the legacy of the former British prime minister [[Margaret Thatcher]] who had died that month, and to debate tax policies and the division of wealth amongst UK citizens.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/programmes/10-oclock-live/episode-guide/series-3/episode-1 |title=Series 3, Episode 1, 10 O'Clock Live |publisher=Channel 4 |date=24 April 2013 |accessdate=28 April 2013}}</ref>
In 2015, she deliberately gained and lost weight over the course of several months, in an attempt to show that obese people can diet successfully. Her progress was carefully documented by a camera crew and then played on a programme called ''My Fat Story'' for [[TLC (UK and Ireland)|TLC]].<ref name=grigg>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/foodanddrink/11317274/Katie-Hopkins-what-fat-people-need-is-a-kick-up-the-a-.html|title=Hopkins: what fat people need is a kick up the a--|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=8 January 2015|first=Casilda|last=Grigg|accessdate=15 January 2015}}</ref> Hopkins gained and lost {{convert|3|st|lb kg}} over the course of the programme.<ref name=Lockhart>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/foodanddrink/11316692/Katie-Hopkins-Im-still-the-biggest-bitch-in-Britain.html|title=Katie Hopkins: 'I'm still the biggest bitch in Britain'|first=Keely|last=Lockhart|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=6 February 2015|accessdate=4 March 2015}}</ref> TLC claimed an audience figure of 10 million in the UK and US for the programme.<ref name="Sweney181215">{{cite news|last=Sweney|first=Mark|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/dec/18/katie-hopkins-tv-chat-show-axed|title=Katie Hopkins' TV chatshow axed|work=The Guardian|date=18 December 2015|accessdate=18 December 2015}}</ref>
Later that year, she began her own chat show, ''[[If Katie Hopkins Ruled the World]]'' on the digital channel [[TLC (UK and Ireland)|TLC]]. She said she wanted to bring a new variation to chat and panel shows.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/aug/06/if-katie-hopkins-ruled-the-world-tv-show-daily-mail-liz-jones|title=Katie Hopkins' TV show: 'I’m not playing the part of a pantomime villain’|first=Tara|last=Conlan|newspaper=The Guardian|date=6 August 2015|accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref> The series was dropped in December, after the first series, owing to low audience ratings.<ref name="Sweney181215"/>
From April 2016 to May 2017, Hopkins presented a [[Sunday morning talk show]] on [[LBC]], a London-based national talk and phone-in radio station.<ref>{{cite news|last=Verdier|first=Hannah|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/apr/14/katie-hopkins-lbc-show-review-controversy-washed-down-with-offence|title=The Katie Hopkins LBC show review: controversy washed down with offence|work=The Guardian|date=14 April 2016|accessdate=14 April 2016}}</ref> She had previously worked as a guest presenter for the station.<ref>{{cite news|last=Rea |first=James |url=http://www.lbc.co.uk/katie-hopkins-and-andrew-castle-get-lbc-shows-128025 |title=Katie Hopkins And Andrew Castle Get LBC Shows |publisher=LBC |date=4 April 2016 |accessdate=4 April 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407040126/http://www.lbc.co.uk/katie-hopkins-and-andrew-castle-get-lbc-shows-128025 |archivedate=7 April 2016 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Plunkett|first=John|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/apr/04/katie-hopkins-lbc-radio-show|title=Katie Hopkins to host LBC radio show|work=The Guardian|date=4 April 2016|accessdate=4 April 2016}}</ref> "The snarling facade remained", wrote Fiona Sturges for ''[[The Independent]]'' in April 2015 after one such broadcast. "But even Hopkins knows when to tone down the panto villain act".<ref>{{cite news|last=Sturges|first=Fiona|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/reviews/katie-hopkins-lbc-review-yes-katie-was-crass-but-lbc-bosses-should-take-the-blame-10196591.html|title=spewed frothing bile, but radio bosses should take the blame|work=The Independent|date=22 April 2015|accessdate=4 April 2016}}</ref> LBC announced Hopkins' departure on 26 May 2017, 'effective immediately', following her comments on Twitter soon after the [[#Manchester Arena bombing|Manchester Arena bombing]], in which Hopkins claimed "we need a final solution".<ref name="The Independent"/><ref name="The Guardian"/> Speaking about her departure a few days later on [[Fox News]], she said a deal had been made with LBC not to speak about it, but suggested it was part of a "silencing" of people with right-wing views.<ref>{{cite news|first=Jonathan |last=Mitchell |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/uk/katie-hopkins-claims-there-is-a-silencing-of-the-right-after-lbc-axing-a3551711.html |title=Katie Hopkins claims there is a 'silencing of the right' after LBC axing |newspaper=London Evening Standard |date=29 May 2017 |accessdate=3 June 2017}}</ref> Following Hopkins' departure, LBC audience figures rose 18%.<ref>https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/katie-hopkins-lbc-radio-listeners-audience-chris-evans-bbc-highest-paid-radio-2-nick-grimshaw-radio-a7874321.html</ref>
Hopkins said she is "pushing back the walls closing in on freedom of speech" at a Church and Media conference in October 2015. Claiming to be "the new Jesus" during her speech, she said: "I have never apologised for anything I’ve said. I find it very disappointing when people apologise. You should have the positive moral attitude to stand by what you say".<ref>{{cite news|last=Sherwood|first=Harriet|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/oct/13/im-the-new-jesus-katie-hopkins-tells-church-conference|title=I'm the new Jesus, Katie Hopkins tells church conference|work=The Guardian|date=13 October 2015|accessdate=4 May 2017}}</ref><ref name="Powell">{{cite news|last=Powell|first=Emma|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/showbiz/celebrity-news/katie-hopkins-says-she-is-the-new-jesus-and-refuses-to-apologise-for-controversial-comments-a3089916.html|title=Katie Hopkins says she is the 'new Jesus' – and refuses to apologise for controversial comments|work=London Evening Standard|date=13 October 2015|accessdate=20 January 2016}}</ref>
===Print and websites=== Early in her public career, Hopkins wrote a column for Exeter's ''[[Express & Echo]]'' newspaper, but her articles ceased after an online poll in October 2007 found 84% of readers wanted the feature to end.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/devon/7037846.stm|title=Apprentice Katie is 'fired' again|publisher=BBC News|date=10 October 2007|accessdate=16 April 2016}}</ref>
At the end of October 2013, it emerged that Hopkins had joined ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' as a weekly columnist.<ref name="Guardian311013"/> with the newspaper promoting her as "Britain's most controversial columnist".<ref name="Dearden010815"/> Hopkins in February 2015 defended her remarks and those of her critics, commenting: "I welcome it because I've had my opinion and it's only right that people have theirs. I welcome the debate and the fact that people are getting involved."<ref name=Lockhart/>
She left ''The Sun'' for the [[Mail Online]] website, the online companion to the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' in autumn 2015.<ref name="Sweney240915">{{cite news|last=Sweney|first=Mark|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/sep/24/katie-hopkins-leaves-the-sun-to-join-mail-online|title=Katie Hopkins leaves the Sun to join Mail Online|work=The Guardian|date=24 September 2015|accessdate=24 September 2015}}</ref> ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' contributor [[Bryony Gordon]] wrote in April 2015 that media organisations have "a tipping point here, where the marketing men and women don't want to be associated with reality TV's very own Adolf Hitler. But so far that doesn't seem to have happened."<ref>{{cite news|last=Gordon|first=Bryony|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/11549372/Katie-Hopkins-is-a-monster-of-our-own-making.html|title=Katie Hopkins is a monster of our own making|work=The Daily Telegraph|location=London|date=20 April 2015|accessdate=16 April 2016}}</ref> The ''Mail'' published a page one article in June 2017 expressing its low opinion of the liberal ''[[The Guardian]]'' newspaper, which had attacked it for its coverage of the [[2017 Finsbury Park attack|attack on the Finsbury Park mosque]] and also referred to Hopkins. It "was a lie" to say Hopkins wrote for the ''Daily Mail'', it asserted. "''The Guardian'' and its writer know that Ms Hopkins has nothing to do with the ''Daily Mail'', but works for Mail Online – a totally separate entity".<ref>{{cite news|last=Ponsford|first=Dominic|url=http://www.pressgazette.co.uk/mail-online-is-totally-separate-entity-to-daily-mail-paper-claims-over-katie-hopkins-column-confusion/|title='Fake news', 'fascist left', 'purveyors of hate' – ''Daily Mail'' declares all-out war on ''The Guardian''|work=Press Gazette|date=22 June 2017|accessdate=28 November 2017}}</ref> The ''Daily Mail'' newspaper and Mail Online are part of the same group, with the same editor or editor-in-chief.<ref>{{cite news|last=Barnett|first=Steven|url=https://theconversation.com/daily-mail-vs-the-guardian-why-did-editor-paul-dacre-lose-his-rag-80034|title=''Daily Mail'' vs ''The Guardian'': why did editor Paul Dacre lose his rag?|work=The Conversation|date=23 June 2017|accessdate=28 November 2017}}</ref> Her last column for the ''Mail'' website was published on 5 October 2017.<ref name="Ruddick271117"/> In a late November 2017 statement from her employers to the ''[[Press Gazette]]'', it emerged that Hopkins Mail contract had not been renewed by "mutual consent". A large number of Tweets from her Twitter account were deleted around the same time.<ref name="Mayhew271117"/>
A few days before, a video was posted online of Hopkins' appearance at the [[David Horowitz Freedom Center]] in Florida earlier in November 2017. "It's such a pleasure to be amongst people that are prepared to fight for their country" she said, asserting it is "our time". She continued: "We can commit to arm ourselves, not just with the help of the [[National Rifle Association|NRA]]".<ref name="Dearden271117">{{cite news|last=Dearden|first=Lizzie|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/press/katie-hopkins-muslims-far-right-speech-mailonline-racism-islamophobia-david-horowitz-freedom-center-a8078356.html|title=Katie Hopkins gave speech attacking Muslims to far-right group days before leaving Mail Online 'by mutual consent'|work=The Independent|date=27 November 2017|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref> In her opinion, there is a "Muslim mafia" in certain areas of Britain and "institutionalised discrimination against whites" in the UK as a whole.<ref name="Dearden271117"/>
In January 2018, Hopkins joined [[The Rebel Media]], a Canadian far-right website, on which [[Tommy Robinson (activist)|Tommy Robinson]], founder of the [[English Defence League]], is also a contributor.<ref name="Ruddick"/> In her first column on her own Hopkins World outlet, she wrote: "When so many platforms are under the control of the Saudis, tied to fickle commercial advertisers or beholden to special interests and religious lobbyists, it is a real thrill to find a place for us to speak without censorship".<ref name="Ruddick"/>
==Views== ===Islam=== Hopkins is [[Criticism of Islam|anti-Islam]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2018/06/05/anti-muslim-roundup-6518 |title=Anti-Muslim roundup: 6/5/18 |date=5 June 2018 |publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite What to Know About the Deeply Racial Issue |url=http://fortune.com/2018/08/23/trump-white-farmers-south-africa/ |publisher=''[[Fortune (magazine)]]'' |date=23 August 2018}}</ref> She has contended that immigration and multiculturalism are intended to make white people minorities.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Rebel Media-branded retirement savings fund is not happening |url=https://www.macleans.ca/news/canada/the-rebel-media-branded-retirement-savings-fund-is-not-happening/ |publisher=''[[Maclean's]]'' |date=24 July 2018}}</ref> ''[[Yahoo News]]'' reported it was "her intention was to ‘expose’ the white genocide" happening to farmers in South Africa.<ref>{{cite news|title=Katie Hopkins allegedly detained at Johannesburg airport for 'spreading racial hatred' |url=https://uk.news.yahoo.com/katie-hopkins-allegedly-detained-johannesburg-airport-spreading-racial-hatred-143248388.html |publisher=''[[Yahoo News]]'' |date=6 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Katie Hopkins has been allowed to leave South Africa after being 'detained' |url=https://uk.news.yahoo.com/katie-hopkins-allowed-leave-south-africa-detained-130143584.html |publisher=''[[Yahoo News]]'' |date=7 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=A-hole in a K-hole: Katie Hopkins’ ketamine adventures |url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lostinshowbiz/2018/feb/08/a-hole-in-a-k-hole-katie-hopkins-ketamine-adventures |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |date=8 February 2018}}</ref> She also visited to report on 'anti-white racism'.<ref>{{cite news|title=No, Katie Hopkins, there is no white genocide in South Africa |url=https://www.newstatesman.com/world/africa/2018/05/no-katie-hopkins-there-no-white-genocide-south-africa |publisher=''[[New Statesman]]'' |date=22 May 2018}}</ref>
==Controversies==
Since ''The Apprentice'', Hopkins has frequently featured in the media for making controversial remarks, being described in several media outlets as a "professional [[internet troll|troll]]".<ref name=autogenerated3>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2014/dec/19/friday-2-januarys-best-tv|title=Friday 2nd January's Best TV|newspaper=The Guardian|date=19 December 2014|accessdate=19 January 2015}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2014/12/02/katie-hopkins-gets-slayed-twitter-x-factor-stereo-kicks-singer-tom-mann_n_6253542.html|title=Katie Hopkins Gets Slayed on Twitter By X Factor Stereo Kicks Singer Tom Mann|work=HuffPost|date=2 December 2014|accessdate=19 January 2015}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.co.uk/stereo-kicks/news/stereo-kicks-burn-katie-hopkins-on-twitter|title=Stereo Kicks Burn Katie Hopkins on Twitter|publisher=MTV|date=2 December 2014|accessdate=19 January 2015}}</ref> She has described herself as a "conduit for truth", declaring what other people think but are too scared to say.<ref name="Usborne2014">{{cite news|last=Usborne|first=Simon|title=A day with Katie Hopkins: Separating the Apprentice 'superbitch' from her soundbites|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/features/a-day-with-katie-hopkins-separating-the-apprentice-superbitch-from-her-soundbites-8706555.html|accessdate=16 February 2014|newspaper=Independent|date=12 July 2013}}</ref>
===Social class=== During an appearance on [[ITV Network|ITV's]] ''[[This Morning (TV programme)|This Morning]]'' in July 2013, Hopkins revealed she would stop her children playing with their classmates based on their [[given name]]s. She revealed a particular dislike for "lower class" names like Charmaine, Chantelle, and [[Chardonnay (name)|Chardonnay]], which met with disapproval from co-host [[Holly Willoughby]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Wallwork|first=Ellen|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2014/09/30/holly-willoughby-baby-name-katie-hopkins-teases-they-clearly-had-sex-in-chester_n_7321976.html|title=Holly Willoughby Baby Name: Katie Hopkins Teases 'They Clearly Had Sex In Chester'|work=HuffPost|date=30 September 2014|accessdate=16 April 2016}}</ref> Hopkins said that she did not like "geographical location names" either. After Willoughby's colleague, [[Phillip Schofield]], pointed out that she had given the name [[India (given name)|India]] to one of her daughters, Hopkins asserted that India is "not related to a place".<ref name="Battersby">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/katie-hopkins-branded-an-insufferable-snob-after-this-morning-debate-on-childrens-names-8690468.html|title=Katie Hopkins branded an 'insufferable snob' after This Morning debate on children's names|first=Matilda|last=Battersby|date=5 July 2013|accessdate=9 July 2013|work=[[The Independent]]}}</ref> A viewers' poll conducted by the ''This Morning'' programme indicated that 91% of respondents disagreed with Hopkins' opinion.<ref name="Battersby"/>
Appearing as a panellist on [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]]'s ''[[The Big Benefits Row: Live]]'' in February 2014, she was accused by [[Terry Christian]] amongst others of only expressing her controversial opinions to make money from media appearances.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2014/02/04/katie-hopkins-annabel-giles-the-big-benefits-row-channel-5_n_4721468.html|title=Katie Hopkins Comes To Blows With Annabel Giles On 'The Big Benefits Row'|work=Huffington Post|date=4 February 2014|first=Ashley|last=Percival|accessdate=21 July 2018}}</ref> Hopkins has said that financial motives are not the reason she speaks out, and received a "relatively modest" fee of £300 when she was on ''This Morning'' speaking about children's names.<ref name="Usborne2014"/>
In a February 2014 interview with [[Decca Aitkenhead]] for ''The Guardian'', Hopkins was asked if she is a snob: "Oh, definitely yeah, 100%. I think it's really important to be snobby".<ref name="Aitkenhead"/>
===Illness and fatalities in the UK=== Hopkins posted a tweet referring to Scottish [[life expectancy]] predictions based upon a 2011 [[NHS Scotland]] report, "Healthy Life Expectancy in Scotland: Update of trends to 2010". This tweet was posted following a heated debate on Scottish Independence during an edition of ''[[The Wright Stuff]]'' on which Hopkins was a panellist. In the wake of the [[2013 Glasgow helicopter crash]], the tweet raised widespread condemnation among Twitter users. Hopkins retorted "Following Independence I will only be the Biggest Bitch in England", and described people's reactions as "[[political correctness|PC]] tastic".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/dec/02/katie-hopkins-twitter-glasgow-helicopter-crash-apprentice|title=Katie Hopkins apologises for timing of tweet about Scottish life expectancy|newspaper=The Guardian|date=2 December 2013|accessdate=4 March 2015}}</ref> An online petition to ban Hopkins from shows such as ITV's ''This Morning'' and ''The Wright Stuff'' on Channel 5 gained over 75,000 signatures. Hopkins issued an apology the following Monday, restating that her original remark was in reference to the NHS report and was simply bad timing.<ref>{{cite news|last=Baird|first=Dugald|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/dec/03/katie-hopkins-petition-scotland-glasgow-twitter|title=Katie Hopkins petition passes 75,000 as she explains life expectancy tweet|newspaper=The Guardian|date=3 December 2013|accessdate=4 March 2015}}</ref> ITV said on 5 December 2013 that "We have no plans for Katie Hopkins to appear on ''This Morning'' at this present time".<ref>{{cite news|last=Blundy|first=Rachel|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/celebritynews/katie-hopkins-dropped-from-this-morning-after-thousands-sign-petition-in-wake-of-ill-timed-scotland-8983264.html|title=Katie Hopkins 'dropped' from This Morning after thousands sign petition in wake of ill-timed Scotland tweet|work=London Evening Standard|date=5 December 2013|accessdate=16 April 2016}}</ref>
On 31 December 2014, police announced they were investigating complaints they had received concerning Hopkins' tweets about [[Ebola virus disease in the United Kingdom#2014 returning aid worker|Pauline Cafferkey]], a Scottish aid worker who was diagnosed with [[Ebola virus disease|Ebola]] after returning to the UK from [[Sierra Leone]]. Hopkins had tweeted: "Little sweaty jocks, sending us Ebola bombs in the form of sweaty Glaswegians just isn't cricket. Scottish NHS sucks."<ref name=bbc_ebola>{{cite news| url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-glasgow-west-30641705| title = Katie Hopkins' tweets on 'Ebola bombs' examined by police| date = 31 December 2014| accessdate = 3 January 2015| publisher = BBC News}}</ref> No evidence of criminality was found by the police.<ref>{{cite news|title=No charges over Katie Hopkins' tweets on 'sweaty jocks'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-glasgow-west-32945786|accessdate=30 May 2015|date=30 May 2015}}</ref> On 7 April 2015, Hopkins made a series of tweets suggesting that people with [[dementia]] are "bed blockers" who take up scarce hospital beds and implied they would be better off dead. Her comments were condemned by leading UK Alzheimer's charities.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/health/news/11520748/Katie-Hopkins-slurs-on-dementia-patients-provoke-anger-from-charities.html|title = Katie Hopkins' slurs on dementia patients provoke anger from charities|last = Donnelly|first = Laura|date = 7 April 2015|work = The Daily Telegraph|access-date = 8 April 2015}}</ref>
After five Londoners drowned at [[Camber Sands]] in August 2016, Hopkins tweeted a poll mocking the identities of the deceased.<ref name="Blair250816">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/katie-hopkins-twitter-camber-sands-death-poll-police-report-a7209081.html|title=Katie Hopkins reported to Twitter by police over Camber Sands deaths poll|work=[[The Independent]]|first=Olivia|last=Blair|date=25 August 2016|accessdate=25 August 2016}}</ref> [[Sussex Police]] reported the tweet to Twitter under the headings of "abusive or harmful" and "disrespectful or offensive".<ref name="Blair250816"/> They decided while the tweet was distasteful it was not criminal.<ref name="Blair250816"/> The tweet was deleted.<ref name="Blair250816"/>
===Pakistani men and Rochdale=== Hopkins objected to Rochdale commemorating National Pakistan Day on 23 March 2015 and claimed to base her objection on a [[Rochdale sex trafficking gang|Rochdale sex trafficking case]] involving nine predominantly Pakistani men and forty-seven white victims.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/mar/29/katie-hopkins-reported-police-race-hate-rochdale-pakistani-sex-abuse|title=Katie Hopkins accused of race hate by linking Pakistani men with sex abuse|newspaper=The Guardian|date=29 March 2015|accessdate=29 March 2015}}</ref> In a series of tweets, she posted images of the felons with the caption "are these your friends too?" On 29 March 2015, Hopkins was reported to the police by Labour MP [[Simon Danczuk]] for possible race hate crimes.<ref name=Rochdale1>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/article/32112029/katie-hopkins-reported-to-police-for-race-hate-by-politician|title=Katie Hopkins reported to police for race hate by politician|publisher=BBC News|date=30 March 2015|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref> In response, Hopkins said "I asked fair questions and I think it's important that someone has the balls to speak out".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/katie-hopkins-accuses-labour-mp-simon-danczuk-of-reporting-her-to-the-police-to-divert-attention-away-from-his-porn-habit-10148144.html|title=Katie Hopkins accuses Labour MP Simon Danczuk of reporting her to the police to divert attention away from his porn habit|first=Jenn|last=Selby|newspaper=The Independent|date=1 April 2015|accessdate=8 April 2015}}</ref>
===Migrants=== On 17 April 2015, Hopkins wrote a column in ''The Sun'' in comparing migrants to "cockroaches" and "feral humans" and said they were "spreading like the norovirus". She wrote that gunships should be used to stop migrants from crossing the Mediterranean.<ref>{{cite news|last=Plunkett|first=John|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/apr/20/katie-hopkins-sun-migrants-article-petition-nears-180000-mark|title=Katie Hopkins compares migrants to 'cockroaches' and suggests using gunships to stop them crossing the Mediterranean|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=20 April 2015|accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref><ref name="ITV180415">{{cite news|url=http://www.itv.com/news/2015-04-18/katie-hopkins-compares-migrants-to-cockroaches-and-suggests-using-gunships-to-stop-them-crossing-the-mediterranean/|title=Katie Hopkins compares migrants to 'cockroaches' and suggests using gunships to stop them crossing the Mediterranean|publisher=[[ITV News]]|date=18 April 2015|accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref><ref name="Gander">{{cite news|last=Gander|first=Kashmira|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/hateful-katie-hopkins-column-on-migrants-causes-twitter-backlash-as-russell-brand-wades-into-debate-10186342.html|title='Hateful' Katie Hopkins column on migrants causes Twitter backlash, as Russell Brand wades into debate|work=[[The Independent]]|date=17 April 2015|accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref> Her remarks were condemned by the [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights|United Nations High Commission for Human Rights]], [[Prince Zeid bin Ra'ad|Zeid Ra'ad Al Hussein]].<ref name="Stone240415">{{cite news|last=Stone|first=Jon|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/katie-hopkins-migrant-cockroaches-column-resembles-progenocide-propaganda-says-the-un-10201959.html|title=Katie Hopkins' migrant 'cockroaches' column resembles pro-genocide propaganda, says the UN|work=The Independent|date=24 April 2015|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref> In a statement released on 24 April 2015, he urged the UK to "curb incitement to hatred" by its "tabloid newspapers" and stated that Hopkins used "language very similar to that employed by Rwanda's ''[[Kangura]]'' newspaper and [[Radio Télévision Libre des Mille Collines|Radio Mille Collines]] during the run up to the [[Rwandan Genocide|1994 genocide]]", and noted that both media organisations were subsequently convicted by an international tribunal of public incitement to commit [[genocide]].<ref name="Stone240415"/>
Hopkins' column also drew criticism on Twitter, including from [[Russell Brand]], to whom Hopkins responded by accusing Brand's "[[champagne socialist]] humanity" of neglecting taxpayers.<ref name="Gander"/> Simon Usborne, writing in ''[[The Independent]]'', compared her use of the word "cockroach" to previous uses by the [[Nazism|Nazis]] and just before the [[Rwandan Genocide]] by its perpetrators.<ref name="Usborne2015">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/katie-hopkins-when-is-enough-enough-10186490.html|title=Katie Hopkins has just written a piece so hateful that it might give Hitler pause – why was it published?|work=The Independent|last=Usborne|first=Simon|date=18 April 2015}}</ref> He suspected that if any other contributor had written the piece it would not have been published and questioned her continued employment by the newspaper.<ref name="Usborne2015"/> [[Zoe Williams]] commented in ''[[The Guardian]]'': "It is no joke when people start talking like this. We are not 'giving her what she wants' when we make manifest our disgust. It is not a free speech issue. I'm not saying gag her: I'm saying fight her".<ref>{{cite news|first=Zoe|last=Williams|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/apr/19/katie-hopkins-migrants-vermin-darkest-history-drownings|title=Katie Hopkins calling migrants vermin recalls the darkest events of history|newspaper=The Guardian|date=19 April 2015|accessdate=21 July 2018}}</ref>
A [[Change.org]] petition was initiated with the aim of getting ''The Sun'' to sack Hopkins. By 26 April, it had attracted over 310,000 signatures.<ref>{{cite news|title=The migrant petition that's not about Katie Hopkins|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/blogs-trending-32395272|accessdate=21 April 2015|publisher=BBC News|date=21 April 2015}}</ref> In early September, ''The Sun'' retweeted an earlier comment from Hopkins expressing her disinterest in migrants. The tweet was pulled after the Prime Minister [[David Cameron]] publicly announced Britain would do more to help those seeking asylum in the UK.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/mediamonkeyblog/2015/sep/03/why-did-sun-delete-katie-hopkins-gunships-to-stop-migrants-tweet|title=Why did Sun delete Katie Hopkins 'Gunships to stop migrants' tweet?|newspaper=The Guardian|date=3 September 2015|accessdate=4 September 2015}}</ref> A further Change.org petition for Hopkins to be replaced with 50,000 Syrian refugees gained more than 20,000 signatures in less than 48 hours in September 2015.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Ben Fletcher|title=Swap Katie Hopkins for 50,000 Refugees|publisher=[[change.org]]|accessdate=6 September 2015|location=Tickhill, United Kingdom}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://i100.independent.co.uk/article/someone-set-up-a-petition-to-swap-katie-hopkins-with-50000-syrian-refugees--Z1qRC1eirl|title=Someone set up a petition to swap Katie Hopkins with 50,000 Syrian refugees|work=i100|accessdate=6 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2015/09/05/swap-katie-hopkins-for-50000-refugees-petition_n_8093854.html?1441479098&ncid=tweetlnkushpmg00000067|title=Swap Katie Hopkins For 50,000 Refugees Petition Sees 20,000 Signatures in Just Over A Day|work=The Huffington Post UK|accessdate=6 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/uk/petition-launched-to-swap-katie-hopkins-for-50000-syrian-refugees-a2927656.html|title=Petition launched to swap Katie Hopkins for 50,000 Syrian refugees|author=Tom Marshall|date=5 September 2015|work=London Evening Standard|accessdate=6 September 2015}}</ref>
Peter Herbert, chair of the Society of Black Lawyers, reported Hopkins and ''The Sun'' to Sir [[Bernard Hogan-Howe]], the [[Metropolitan Police]] Commissioner. Hopkins was questioned and not charged, and subsequently criticised the police for purportedly criminalising opinion, and stated that she would set up a Society of White Lawyers.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Saul|first1=Heather|title=Katie Hopkins tweets about 'setting up society for white lawyers' after Met Police decide against charging her over allegations of inciting racial hatred|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/katie-hopkins-tweets-about-setting-up-society-for-white-lawyers-after-met-police-decide-against-a6720436.html|accessdate=5 November 2015|work=The Independent|date=4 November 2015}}</ref> By December 2016, the original article had been removed from ''The Sun''{{'}}s website.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://politicalscrapbook.net/2016/12/the-sun-deletes-katie-hopkins-article-calling-refugees-cockroaches-after-stop-funding-hate-campaign/|title=''The Sun'' Deletes Katie Hopkins' Article Calling Refugees 'Cockroaches' After Stop Funding Hate Campaign|work=Political Scrapbook|date=14 December 2016|accessdate=14 December 2016}}</ref>
===Donald Trump=== Hopkins supported [[Donald Trump]]'s Republican presidential nomination in the ''Daily Mail'' during December: "I hear cries that he is a blithering idiot. I have often been called a deranged fool. But if this were true you could ignore me, ignore us, {{sic|imaging}} the two of us shouting naked at the rain. It's because we articulate sentiments repressed by the politically correct consensus that we have a voice".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/media/2015/12/world-ends-donald-trump-discovers-respected-columnist-katie-hopkins-supports|title=World ends as Donald Trump discovers 'respected columnist' Katie Hopkins supports him|work=New Statesman|date=10 December 2016|accessdate=11 November 2016}}</ref> Hopkins defended Trump's [[Immigration policy of Donald Trump#Proposed Muslim immigration ban|remarks that all Muslims should be banned from entering the United States]]. Trump later thanked Hopkins for her support and for her "powerful writing on the U.K.'s Muslim problems", calling her a "respected journalist",<ref name="Blair101215">{{cite news|last=Blair|first=Olivia|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/donald-trump-thanks-respected-columnist-katie-hopkins-for-her-praising-article-a6767976.html|title=Donald Trump thanks 'respected columnist' Katie Hopkins|work=The Independent|date=10 December 2015|accessdate=11 November 2015}}</ref><ref name="Hawkins">{{cite news|last=Hawkins|first=Derek|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2017/05/24/we-need-a-final-solution-british-columnist-tweets-then-deletes-after-manchester-bombing/|title='We need a final solution,' British columnist tweets – then deletes – after Manchester bombing|work=The Washington Post|date=24 May 2017|accessdate=24 May 2017}}</ref> although the [[Metropolitan Police Service|Metropolitan Police]] and the [[Mayor of London]], [[Boris Johnson]] among others, rejected his comments that there are 'no go' areas of London for non-Muslims. Hopkins asserted that Britain is in part "radicalised" and "it does nobody any favours to deny the obvious".<ref name="Blair101215"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Hopkins|first=Steven|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2015/12/10/katie-hopkins-defends-donald-trumps-muslim-ban_n_8767842.html|title=Donald Trump: Katie Hopkins Backs US Presidential Candidate Saying She Doesn't 'Buy Divide' Between 'Peaceful And Extremist Muslims'|work=HuffPost|date=10 December 2015|accessdate=11 December 2015}}</ref> When asked by BBC's ''[[Daily Politics]]'' presenter [[Andrew Neil]] in a December 2015 interview to name the "swathes" of Britain that are no-go areas for non-Muslims, Hopkins replied that she couldn't for "legal reasons". When Neil pointed out there could be no legal problems with identifying an area she continued to refuse, saying only “I know those places exist".<ref>{{cite news|last=Goodfellow|first=Mollie|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/katie-hopkins-no-go-areas-non-muslims-in-andrew-neil-bbc-daily-politics-interview-legally-accurate-a6769516.html|title=Katie Hopkins admits she cannot name 'no-go' areas for non-Muslims in Andrew Neil BBC Daily Politics interview|work=The Independent|date=11 December 2015|accessdate=12 October 2017}}</ref>
===Racism, racial profiling, and Black Lives Matter=== In January 2017, a caller to her LBC programme named Joseph said she came over as racist, following which she said: "I genuinely believe 'racist' as a word has been used so much. I am sorry for the word racist in a way. I love language so much ... it's like a regular word now, it's lost all meaning to me". When tweeting the clip she added, "Call me racist. I don't care. I will stand up for white women being raped because you're scared to offend Muslims".<ref>{{cite news|last=Chandler|first=Mark|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/uk/outrage-as-katie-hopkins-shares-neonazi-praise-after-racism-debate-a3430926.html|title=Outrage as Katie Hopkins shares neo-Nazi praise after 'racism' debate|work=London Evening Standard|date=2 January 2017|accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref> Hopkins tweeted shortly afterwards: "Racial profiling is a good thing, call me racist. I don't care...it has lost all meaning". She later briefly retweeted a favourable response from an account named Anti Juden SS, whose avatar featured the [[Nazi swastika|Swastika]] (and the United States flag), later explaining that she had not looked at the handle.<ref>{{cite news|last=Demianyk|first=Graeme|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/katie-hopkins-tweet-racist-neo-nazi_uk_586a91a3e4b0f24da6e93af7|title=Katie Hopkins Shares 'Neo-Nazi' Praise After Claiming 'Racism Has Lost All Meaning'|work=HuffPost|date=3 January 2017|accessdate=23 May 2017}} The ellipsis is in Hopkins' original tweet</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Gold|first=Tanya|url=https://www.spectator.co.uk/2017/01/press-regulation-will-be-a-boon-to-anti-journalists-like-katie-hopkins/#|title=Press regulation will be a boon to anti-journalists like Katie Hopkins|work=The Spectator|date=7 January 2017|accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref>
Sharing a poster on Twitter for the [[Netflix]] series ''[[Dear White People (TV series)|Dear White People]]'' at the beginning of May 2017, Hopkins added: "Dear black people. If your lives matter why do you stab and shoot each other so much". Although, the tweet was deleted, users of the social media site circulated screenshots of what appeared to be a reference to the [[Black Lives Matter]] movement in the United States.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stolworthy|first=Jacob|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/katie-hopkins-dear-white-people-netflix-series-black-lives-matter-racist-tweet-a7713646.html|title=Katie Hopkins accused of racism after Dear White People tweet|work=The Independent|date=2 May 2017|accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref> In August 2016, she urged the London Mayor [[Sadiq Khan]] to use [[Water cannon#United Kingdom|water cannon]] against Black Lives Matter protesters at [[Heathrow Airport]], who had chained themselves to the tarmac of an approach road.<ref>{{cite news|last=Chandler|first=Mark|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/london/black-lives-matter-katie-hopkins-causes-outrage-after-calling-for-water-cannon-to-be-used-against-a3313331.html|title=Black Lives Matter: Katie Hopkins causes outrage after calling for water cannon to be used against Heathrow protesters|work=London Evening Standard|date=5 August 2016|accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref>
In early 2018 Hopkins was detained and had her passport briefly confiscated in South Africa for allegedly spreading racial hatred.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2018/may/24/katie-hopkins-wins-complaint-against-mirror-for-ketamine-headline|title=Katie Hopkins wins complaint against Mirror for ketamine headline|first=Jim|last=Waterson Media|date=24 May 2018|accessdate=21 July 2018}}</ref>
==={{anchor}}Manchester Arena bombing=== Regarding the Manchester Arena bombing, Hopkins wrote that "Britain is faced with some hard questions the people charged with protecting us are going to have to answer sooner or later". Hopkins asserted that the suicide bomber, Salman Abedi, was known to the police, and questioned how he was permitted to re-enter Britain unchallenged after visiting Libya. "Our leaders allow such deeply suspicious characters back into Britain," wrote Hopkins, "and then expect us to swallow their lies that we will not give in to terror?"<ref>{{cite news | last = Hopkins | first = Katie | date = 24 May 2017 | title = The Politicians Now Have Hundreds of Troops Protecting Them While Telling The Rest of Us To Keep Calm, Stay 'United' And Carry On. But Who Is Going To Protect OUR Kids From The Terror THEY Let In? | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-4539242/KATIE-HOPKINS-ll-protect-kids-terror.html | work = Daily Mail}}</ref> Hopkins also tweeted about the need for a "final solution", the [[Final Solution|Nazis' term]] for the [[The Holocaust|Holocaust]], on the morning following the [[2017 Manchester Arena bombing|May 2017 Manchester Arena bombing]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Dearden|first=Lizzie|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/manchester-bombing-katie-hopkins-final-solution-muslims-arena-terror-attack-phillip-schofield-a7750656.html|title=Manchester bombing: Katie Hopkins reported to police after calling for 'final solution' following terror attack|work=The Independent|date=23 May 2017|accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref> Although the tweet was soon deleted and reworded as a "true solution", Hopkins claimed the original was only a typographical error (she had also misspelled "Manchester").<ref name="Nelson230517">{{cite news|last=Nelson|first=Sara C.|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/manchester-bombing-katie-hopkins-reported-to-police-for-calling-for-final-solution-following-attack_uk_5923ffaee4b094cdba573404|title=Manchester Bombing: Katie Hopkins Twitter Row Sees Owen Jones Call For LBC Boycott|work=HuffPost|date=23 May 2017|accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref> The motive for the attack, and the background of the suicide bomber, was unknown at the time Hopkins made the comment.<ref>{{cite news|last=Mitchell|first=Jonathan|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/crime/manchester-terror-attack-katie-hopkins-sparks-outcry-after-calling-for-final-solution-following-a3545941.html|title=Manchester terror attack: Katie Hopkins sparks outcry after calling for 'final solution' following bombing|work=London Evening Standard|date=23 May 2017|accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Muir|first=Hugh|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/may/23/manchester-rule-of-law-apply-everyone-hate-peddlers-katie-hopkins|title=The rule of law applies to everyone. Even Manchester hate peddlers like Katie Hopkins|work=The Guardian|date=23 May 2017|accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref>
The journalist [[Nick Cohen]] was among those who responded on Twitter: "Even if Hopkins knows nothing of Nazism – which I doubt – her "final solution" can only mean [[ethnic cleansing]]". Others, such as [[Owen Jones (writer)|Owen Jones]], called for a boycott of the LBC radio station while they employ her.<ref name="Nelson230517"/> Interviewed later on Fox News by [[Tucker Carlson]], she called for people to insist on deportations among other responses to terrorist acts. She said: "I used the word 'final solution' in a tweet, and I would not in any way want to use that term and the inference other people lay on that. What I meant was, we need a lasting solution, a resolution to this".<ref name="Hawkins"/><!-- Main passage on her LBC sacking is in 'Subsequent broadcasting work'. Use talk if you disagree with this arrangement. --> The incident led to Hopkins leaving LBC.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-40057165|title=Katie Hopkins to leave LBC 'immediately'|date=26 May 2017|publisher=BBC News}}</ref>
Following the [[2017 London Bridge attack|June 2017 London Bridge attack]] almost a fortnight later, Hopkins called for [[internment|internment camps]] to be used for those suspected of being Muslim extremists on Fox News' ''[[Fox & Friends]]''. The host [[Clayton Morris]] said, on behalf of the network staff, that everyone considered the "idea reprehensible".<ref>{{cite news|last=McDonald|first=Karl|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/uk/fox-news-distances-itself-from-farage-and-hopkins-internment-demands-1-4466308?fff|title=Fox News distances itself from Farage and Hopkins internment demands|work=The Scotsman|agency=Inews|date=5 June 2017|accessdate=5 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Fang|first=Marina|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/fox-news-london-attack_us_59343347e4b075bff0f475f8|title=Fox News Host Disavows Internment Camps, After Panelists Suggest Rounding Up Muslims|work=HuffPost|date=4 June 2017|accessdate=5 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Oppenheim|first=Maya|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/fox-news-katie-hopkins-internment-camp-london-attack-terror-stabbing-muslims-islam-a7775026.html|title=Fox News calls Katie Hopkins' internment camp remarks 'reprehensible'|work=The Independent|date=6 June 2017|accessdate=6 June 2017}}</ref>
Hopkins' comments have been linked in the media with [[hate crimes]] against Muslims. A Muslim man in [[Heckmondwike]] stated that he was attacked by assailants who graffitied his house with Hopkins' tweet, including her misspelling "#Machester".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Finnegan|first1=Stephanie|title=Muslim man attacked by thugs who then vandalised his home quoting a racist Katie Hopkins tweet|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/muslim-man-attacked-thugs-who-13237258|accessdate=26 June 2017|work=Manchester Evening News|date=25 June 2017}}</ref>
===Refugees and migrants in the Mediterranean=== In July 2017, Hopkins flew to [[Catania]] in Sicily to visit a ship known as the C-Star hired by the [[Identitarian movement#In Europe|Defend Europe]] movement, which has the intention of hindering the work of "search and rescue" vessels in the Mediterranean used by charities such as [[Save the Children]] to save trafficked migrants and refugees.<ref name="Oppenheim">{{cite news|last=Oppenheimn|first=Maya|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/katie-hopkins-defend-europe-meeting-far-right-activists-c-star-ship-anti-immigrant-mediterranean-a7857911.html|title=Katie Hopkins branded 'PR machine for extremists' after meeting group aiming to hamper refugee rescues in Med|work=The Independent|date=24 July 2017|accessdate=9 August 2017}}</ref> Defend Europe is supported by the American white-nationalist [[David Duke]] and the neo-Nazi ''[[The Daily Stormer|Daily Stormer]]'' website.<ref name="Mulhall">{{cite news|last=Mulhall|first=Joe|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/jul/21/katie-hopkins-boat-far-right-activists-sicily-migrants|title=Why has Katie Hopkins set sail with a bunch of far-right activists?|work=The Guardian|date=21 July 2017|accessdate=9 August 2017}}</ref>
Hopkins tweets suggested she was actively supporting Defend Europe, rather than covering the subject for her employer: "Looking forward to meeting the crew of the C-Star in Catania tomorrow. Setting out to defend the Med. All this week @MailOnline". She tweeted, and then deleted, an image of herself with a Defend Europe activist also present in Sicily at the time,<!-- reported to be a pseudonym. --> a man known as Peter Sweden, <!-- Sweden has stated he has changed his mind. -->initially reported to be an active [[Holocaust denial|Holocaust denier]].<ref name="Mulhall"/><ref>{{cite news|last=York|first=Chris|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/katie-hopkins-holocaust-denier_uk_596e0e4ee4b010d77673cb92|title=Katie Hopkins Deletes Tweet With Picture of Her Posing With Holocaust Denier|work=HuffPo|date=21 July 2017|accessdate=9 August 2017}} For the Peter Sweden connection, see also {{cite news|last=Finnsiö|first=Morgan|url=http://hopenothate.org.uk/2017/08/01/far-right-vlogger-defend-europe-supporter-peter-swedens-real-identity-revealed/|title=Far-Right Vlogger and Defend Europe Supporter Peter Sweden's Real Identity Revealed|work=Hope Not Hate|date=1 August 2017|accessdate=9 August 2017}}</ref>
An article headlined "Katie Hopkins on NGOs colluding with traffickers in Sicily" was briefly published on the ''Mailonline'' website in mid-July 2017.<ref name="Oppenheim"/> According to a report on the ''[[HuffPo]]'' website, the article offered no evidence to match the title. Shortly after her article was deleted, Save the Children rejected Hopkins' claim that she had "spent time" with the crew of one of their ships. "Nor will she set sail with us on any of our rescue missions", they stated.<ref>{{cite news|last=York|first=Chris|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/katie-hopkins_uk_596f4a08e4b00db3d0f46e11|title=Katie Hopkins in Row With Save The Children As MailOnline Article Mysteriously Disappears|work=HuffPo|date=20 July 2017|accessdate=9 August 2017}}</ref> The deleted ''Mailonline'' article was her only contribution to the planned series.<ref>{{cite news|last=Anglesey|first=Steve|url=http://www.theneweuropean.co.uk/top-stories/brexfactor-katie-hopkins-words-of-hate-are-lost-at-sea-1-5125518|title=Brexfactor: Katie Hopkins’ words of hate are lost at sea|work=The New European|date=28 July 2017|accessdate=9 August 2017}}</ref>
